posts.cooked:
We're a rookie team working on getting our swerve drivebase operational and need help with planning our programming strategy. Our hardware setup includes four donated WCP swerve X flipped corner mounts, each equipped with two Falcon 500s. We plan to purchase four CTRC CANcoders, as they appear to be the most commonly used option, while keeping the CANcoders donated by another team. We're considering whether replacing these with cheaper options from Thrifty Bot is a wise decision. Does anyone have experience using Thrifty Bot encoders, or should we stick with the CTRC ones? As a school-funded team, we can't afford the expensive Pigon IMU, so we'll use our existing NavX 2 with our roboRIO 2.0, meaning we won't have access to CTRC's swerve code generator.

To get started, we assume Java is the way to go due to its extensive documentation. We'll set up the CAN IDs for our hardware using Tuner X and obtain encoder offset values along with gear ratios and chassis length. In this phase, should we use a swerve template from WPILib? What challenges might we face, and how should we begin programming? Is it better to have one programmer work on the code, or should we have multiple? Given that we'll share one Windows computer at school, is this a typical setup and feasible? Have we missed anything important?

Additionally, we'd like to compare the advantages and disadvantages of TBT encoders versus CTRC CANcoders, both of which are absolute-magnetic encoders. Here's what we currently understand:

**CTRC CANcoder:**
- Wired through CAN
- Configurable in Tuner X
- Designed specifically for WCP Swerves

**TBT Encoder:**
- Wired directly to Roborio
- Primarily used with MK modules from SDS

This analysis will help us make informed decisions about our encoder choice and subsequent programming approach.

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked: The Thrifty absolute encoders worked for us. They are an option selection when using YAGSL (Yet Another Generic Swerve Library).
Were you using a WCP Swerve module? What was programming like? It’s good to know, though.

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked: We used SDS MK4I modules and the YAGSL library. With YAGSL, the Thrifty is one of the choices for an absolute encoder that can be made. The lower-level code is invisible to the library user. With CANCoders, the absolute offset can be stored either in the CANCoder or in your code. When using the Thrifty unit, it’s stored only in your code. If you can share a link to your code, you can receive further assistance.

link_counts.title: Welcome to Yet Another Swerve Document | YAGSL

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: There are a lot of online swerve code templates available where you mainly just need to input your swerve constants—encoder offsets, inversion settings for steer, drive, and gear ratios. While WPILIB works well, I used the AdvantageKit TalonFX example project, so it shouldn't matter. Starting simple is key; don't rush to add custom features until you have a reliable base, preferably based on a proven template. Trusting your team to avoid common mistakes like ours might not always happen, but since you're using cancoders, make sure to glue the magnets tightly to prevent shifting issues. If you're using a NavX, using USB as backup power could help avoid disconnections during matches, which means less resetting the gyro. Creating a reset button is a good idea if you haven't already. The number of programmers depends on your skill levels; collaborating and sharing code, even if not everyone works on it together, is still beneficial. Using one computer might be manageable but could be inconvenient; setting up GitHub would likely smooth things out. For foundational knowledge, reviewing the WPIlib documentation about swerve mechanisms and their functions is essential.

Here's the cleaned-up version of your text:

Ah, I see! You're mentioning that you used the PWM cable to connect directly to the roboRio since the thrifty bot encoder can't be integrated with the CAN network. It seems like a cost-effective solution. I'll also bring this up with our mentor to compare between the CANcoder and the Thriftybot Encoder. Additionally, I need to check if the case for the encoder is compatible with our modules. If not, maybe we can 3D print a custom one. The main factor right now is the price difference between the two options.

Just out of curiosity, how does the encoder's performance compare? Is the programming experience similar whether we go with the CANcoder or the Thriftybot? I remember that the CANcoder uses the Phoenix 6 library and can be updated via Tuner X, but I'm not too familiar with the Thriftybot's setup. Any insights would be helpful!

Also, there's an image attached below that might provide more context, but it doesn't seem to load properly. Could you please share the actual image link or check if it's accessible?

GronkBaby mentioned reading the WPIlib documentation to understand how swerve works and the functions of the libraries. :grinning: Sounds good! Just out of curiosity, what encoder is your team using? The assistant replied, "I'm using a combination of OpenCV and custom C++ for image processing."

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: We are using CANcoders (although for 3/4 of the season we just aligned the wheels before the start of every match BCS I couldn’t figure out why the encoders weren’t working smh).

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: You should look into the AdvantageKit Swerve Template created by Team 6328, which comes with setup instructions and NAVX code (along with simulation, etc.). However, you may need to adjust the settings to use the provided NAVX code, but it should work without issues. I highly recommend the CANCoders.

for the recommendations!

I think I need to figure out how to use this new information. Maybe start by understanding what exactly they're suggesting. I should probably break it down step by step. First, identify the key points in their recommendations. Then, plan how to implement them effectively. After that, maybe create a timeline or schedule to follow these steps. It would also help to gather any necessary materials or resources needed for each part. I wonder if there are any potential obstacles I might face along the way. Perhaps I should anticipate those and come up with solutions beforehand. Once everything is ready, I can begin executing each recommendation systematically. I'll keep track of my progress to ensure I stay on course. If something doesn't work as expected, I know to adjust my approach accordingly. Overall, taking it one step at a time should help me successfully utilize these recommendations.
